headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Parker Hannifin Corporation Fiscal 2016 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Parker Hannifin Corporation Fiscal 2016 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Chief Financial Officer, Jon Marten. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Abigail, and good morning to everyone, and welcome to Parker Hannifin's Second Quarter FY '16 Earnings Release Teleconference. joining me today is Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Williams; and President and Chief Operating Officer,
componenttext:
Thank you, Abigail, and good morning to everyone, and welcome to Parker Hannifin's Second Quarter FY '16 Earnings Release Teleconference. 
joining me today is Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Williams; and President and Chief Operating Officer, Lee Banks. 
Today's presentation slides, together with the audio webcast replay, will be accessible on the company's investor information website at phstock.com for 1 year following today's call. 
On Slide #2, you'll find the company's safe harbor disclosure statement addressing forward-looking statements as well as non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations for any reference to non-GAAP financial measures are included in this morning's press release and are posted on Parker's website at phstock.com. 
On Slide #3, for the agenda. To begin, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Williams, will provide highlights for the second quarter of fiscal year 2016. Following Tom's comments, I will provide a review of the company's second quarter FY '16 performance, together with the revised guidance for FY '16. Tom will provide a few summary comments, and then we'll open the call for a Q&A session. 
At this time, I'll turn it over to Tom and ask that you refer to Slide #4.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jon, and welcome to everyone on the call. We appreciate your anticipation today. To start, let me make a few summary comments. It continues to be a very tough environment in many of our end markets and regions. We've responded decisively to adju
componenttext:
Thanks, Jon, and welcome to everyone on the call. We appreciate your anticipation today. 
To start, let me make a few summary comments. It continues to be a very tough environment in many of our end markets and regions. We've responded decisively to adjust to these conditions and delivered impressive margin return on sales, taking control of discretionary spending, boost employment levels across our regions in our company and implemented reduced work schedules, where necessary. This is in addition to the previously announced actions we have underway to restructure our fixed cost and simplification efforts designed to streamline our operations. On both of those fronts, we made excellent progress in the second quarter. 
Given the current headwinds, we are very pleased with the way our teams have responded, as evidenced by a strong margin performance and our ability to control decremental marginal return on sales for the past 3 quarters. We expect strong decremental margin return on sales to continue through our fiscal year-end. 
Moving on to specifics for the second quarter. Sales declined 14% as the effects of the strong dollar negatively impacted us by approximately 4%. And organic sales declined 10%, reflecting end market weakness. Total order rates for the second quarter declined 12% compared with the same quarter last year. Despite this downturn, I am very pleased we delivered total segment operating margins of 12.2% or 13.5% on an adjusted basis. 
During the second quarter, we delivered decremental margin return on sales of 17.2% adjusted, which represents excellent performance in this current business climate. This is really a testament to the way we are fundamentally changing Parker's operating structure. In previous downturns in which we've experienced such a significant reduction in sales volume, we would not have been able to maintain such strong margin performance. The primary drivers for our margin performance include: savings from restructuring we have done in prior periods, immediate and decisive actions on cost-containment and the benefits of a range of simplification initiatives that we have implemented. 
Regarding simplification, we have announced a total of 28 division consolidations. We continue to review our organization and process to reduce overhead cost and simplify processes. This has also helped us to reduce corporate G&A cost. 
Earnings per share for the quarter were $1.33 or $1.52 adjusted for business realignment expenses. Operating cash flow year-to-date includes a $200 million discretionary contribution to the U.S. pension plan. Excluding the contribution year-to-date, operating cash to sales was 9.8%. 
During the second quarter, we repurchased $90 million of Parker shares, bringing our year-to-date total to $400 million. We have now repurchased $1.74 billion under our previous announced $2 billion to $3 billion Parker share repurchase plan over 2 years, which began in October 2014. 
Moving on to discussion on key market trends. As projected in the second quarter, we saw continued pressure in natural resource markets such as oil and gas, agriculture, mining and construction equipment, as the prices of commodities continued to move lower. Our distribution channel remained affected by these markets, particularly those with exposure to oil and gas. We continue to experience general industrial activity weakening due to the knock-on effect from natural resource markets. These challenging markets outweighed positive growth in other markets such as power generation, air-conditioning, turf, rail and heavy-duty truck. 
In summary, our second quarter sales were in line with our October guidance. And Lee will provide some more color on our end markets in the Q&A portion of the call. 
Now switching to our outlook. For fiscal year 2016, we are narrowing the range of our guidance for earnings to $5.90 to $6.30 per share on an adjusted basis, which maintains the earnings midpoint of $6.10 per share. It also means that our implied guidance for the second half of the fiscal year has been adjusted downward for sales and earnings to reflect weaker order entry levels that we experienced in the second quarter. 
We will continue to aggressively manage costs in this challenging environment. Our primary focus will be on maintaining strong decremental margin performance and positioning Parker to weather this downturn and emerge stronger as conditions improve. 
We are also continuing with actions [indiscernible] growth opportunities we have identified under the new Win Strategy. So just to reinforce, our long-term financial objectives to be achieved at the end of fiscal year 2020 are: targeting sales growth of 150 basis points higher than the rate of global industrial production. We're also targeting 17% segment operating margins. And progress towards these goals is expected to deliver on the annual growth rate on earnings per share of 8% over this 5-year period. 
We are excited about opportunities we have to position Parker at the top-quartile company compared with our proxy peers. 
Growth initiatives are underway to further expand our distribution network, commercialize new products and systems, improve the customer experience, expand our service offerings and to leverage e-business Internet of Things capabilities. 
During the second quarter, we developed a comprehensive, long-term plan to accelerate our e-business capabilities. We see opportunities to leverage our distribution channel as part of our strategy to grow our business and create a better customer experience. 
Parker's Internet of Things initiatives became significant momentum in the quarter. We hosted a global connected [indiscernible] that garnered dozens of which Internet of Things application ideas. 
In summary, execution under the new Win Strategy is expected to deliver top-quartile performance versus our proxy peers. 
So for now I hand things back to Jon to review more details in the quarter.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. And at this time, please refer to Slide #5. I'll begin by addressing earnings per share for the quarter. Adjusted earnings per share for the second quarter were $1.33 versus $1.80 for the same quarter a year ago. This excludes business real
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. And at this time, please refer to Slide #5. I'll begin by addressing earnings per share for the quarter. 
Adjusted earnings per share for the second quarter were $1.33 versus $1.80 for the same quarter a year ago. This excludes business realignment expenses of $0.19 and compares to $0.04 for the same quarter last year. 
On Slide #6, you'll find the significant components of the law from adjusted earnings per share of $1.84 for the second quarter FY '15 to $1.52 for the second quarter of this year. The impact of fewer shares outstanding equated to an increase of $0.11 per share. 
Increases to adjusted per share income include: lower corporate G&A expense equating to $0.11 due to reduction in and long-term incentive accruals as well as our simplification efforts, as Tom mentioned. A reduced tax rate for the quarter contributed $0.02, driven by the passage of the U.S. extenders from which the company recognized R&D credit. Reductions to adjusted per share income include lower adjusted segment operating income of $0.39 per share due to the impact of foreign currency and the continued weakening of end market demand and increased interest and other expense that totaled $0.18 per share as compared to the prior year in which various onetime favorable adjustments were recognized. 
Moving to Slide #7 with a review of the total company sales and segment operating margin for the second quarter. Total company organic sales in the first quarter decreased by 9.6% over the same quarter last year. It was a modest 3% contribution to sales in the quarter from acquisitions. Currency impact as a percentage of sales was slightly higher than planned, equating to a negative impact on reported sales of $139 million or 4.4% in the quarter. 
Total company segment operating margins for the second quarter, adjusted for realignment costs incurred in the quarter, was 13.5% versus 14% for the same quarter last year. Restructuring costs incurred in the quarter were $35 million versus $9 million last year. 
The lower adjusted segment operating income this quarter of $366 million versus $439 million last year reflects the impact of reduced volume and unfavorable mix from the continued weakening of several industrial end markets. 
Moving to Slide #8. I'll discuss the business segments starting with Diversified Industrial North America. For the second quarter, North American organic sales decreased by 15.2% as compared to the same quarter last year. There was a modest impact from acquisitions and a negative impact from currency of 1.3% in the quarter. 
Operating margin for the second quarter, adjusted for realignment costs, was 15% of sales versus 16.3% in the prior year. Restructuring expenses incurred totaled $20 million as compared to a nominal spend in the prior year. Adjusted operating income was $174 million as compared to $227 million, driven by reduced volume as a result of softening trends in key end markets. 
I'll continue with the Diversified Industrial segment on Slide #9. Organic sales for the second quarter in the Industrial International segment decreased by 7.1%. Currency negatively impacted sales by 10%. Operating margin for the second quarter, adjusted for realignment cost, was 11% of sales versus 12.3% in the prior year. Restructuring expenses incurred in the quarter totaled $14 million as compared to $9 million in the prior year. Adjusted operating income was $109 million as compared to $146 million, which reflects the impact of the foreign currencies as well as weaker end markets. 
I'll now move to Slide #10 to review the Aerospace Systems segment. Organic revenues decreased nominally at 0.7% for the second quarter. Currency posed a modest negative impact of about 4/10 of 1% [ph]. Sales for the period were maintained as a result of higher aftermarket sales volume, which offset modest year-over-year declines in OEM sales. 
Operating margins for the second quarter, adjusted for realignment cost, was 14.8% of sales versus 12% in the prior year. Nominal realignment expenses were incurred for the period adjusted operating income was $82 million as compared to $67 million, reflecting the favorable mix of higher aftermarket sales volume this quarter combined with reduced development costs as a percentage of sales. 
Moving to Slide #11 with the detail of orders changes by segment. As a reminder, Parker orders represent a trailing average and are reported as a percentage increase of absolute dollars year-over-year, excluding acquisitions, divestitures and currency. The Diversified Industrial segments report on a 3-month rolling average, while Aerospace Systems are based on a 12-month rolling average. 
Total orders were a negative 12% for the quarter end, reflecting the further softening of the Industrial segment stemming from natural resource-related end markets, as Tom mentioned. Diversified Industrial North American orders decreased to negative 15%. Diversified Industrial International orders decreased to negative 10% for the quarter. Aerospace Systems orders improved to a negative 11% for the quarter, which continues to be impacted by lumpy prior-year comparables. 
On Slide #12, we report cash flow from operations. Cash flow from operating activities year-to-date was $347 million, but when adjusted for the $200 million discretionary pension contribution made in the first quarter, cash from operating activities was 9.8% of sales. This compares to 8.4% of sales for the same period last year. 
In addition to the pension contribution, the significant uses of cash year-to-date were $572 million returned to our shareholders via share repurchases of $400 million and dividends of $172 million. $68 million was spent for acquisitions closed during the first quarter. No acquisitions were announced in the second quarter. And we had $75 million for CapEx equating to approximately 1.4% of sales year-to-date. 
Slide #13 provides the -- for FY '16 guidance as outlined. Guidance is being provided on an adjusted basis. Segment operating margins and earnings per share exclude expected business realignment charges of approximately $100 million, which are forecast to be incurred throughout FY '16. 
Total sales are expected to be in the range of negative 12.6% to negative 9.3% or negative 9.9% at the midpoint as compared to the prior year. Adjusted organic growth at the midpoint is negative 7.9%. Currency in the guidance negatively impacts sales by 3.4%, which is nearly all attributable to the international industrial segment. We have calculated the impact of currency to spot rates as of December 31, 2015, and we have held those rates steady as we estimate the resulting year-over-year impact for the balance of FY '16. 
The total Parker adjustment segment operating margins are forecast to be between 14.4% and 14.6%. This compares to 14.9% for FY '15 on an adjusted basis. As Tom mentioned, we're very pleased to be guiding to this level of adjusted segment operating margins, given the magnitude of the end market softness and order decline. 
The guidance for below-the-line items, which includes corporate admin, interest and our category, Other, is $440 million -- $484 million for the year at the midpoint. Our full year tax rate is projected at approximately 28%. The average number of fully diluted shares outstanding used in the full year guidance is 137.1 million shares. 
For the full year, guidance on an adjusted earnings per share basis is $5.90 to $6.30 or $6.10 at the midpoint. This guidance excludes business realignment expenses of approximately $100 million to be incurred in FY '16. Savings from these business realignment initiatives continue to be projected in the amount of $70 million, which are reflected in the segment operating margins. 
Some additional key assumptions for full year 2016 guidance are: sales are divided 49%, first half; 51%, second half. Adjusted segment operating income is divided 49%, first half; 51%, second half. Adjusted EPS is $3.04 in the first half and $3.06 in the second half. Q3 FY '16 adjusted earnings per share is projected to be $1.40 per share at the midpoint, and this excludes $0.17 of business realignment expenses. 
On Slide #14, you'll find the reconciliation of the major components of the revised FY '16 adjusted EPS guidance of $6.10 per share at the midpoint from the prior FY '16 EPS guidance. Increases include $0.12 from reduced tax rate, $0.13 from a reduced corporate G&A, interest and other, and $0.05 from fewer shares outstanding. This is fully offset by a decrease of $0.30 reduction in segment operating income, reflecting further reduced volume and unfavorable mix forecasted within key industrial end markets. 
Please remember that the forecast excludes any future acquisitions or divestitures that might be closed during FY '16. For consistency, we ask that you exclude restructuring expenses from your published estimates. 
This concludes my prepared comments. Tom, I'll turn the call back to you for your summary comments.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. We expect the difficult environment to continue through rest of our fiscal year. As our margins year-to-date indicate, we are responding well. We are making meaningful progress with our restructuring initiatives, which remain on track for th
componenttext:
Thanks, John. We expect the difficult environment to continue through rest of our fiscal year. As our margins year-to-date indicate, we are responding well. We are making meaningful progress with our restructuring initiatives, which remain on track for the year. We also continue to find opportunities to streamline operations through our simplification initiatives. 
I am very encouraged by the response of our Parker team members. It has been just about 1 year since Lee and I took full responsibility for the company. It's certainly been a challenging year from a market perspective. However, our teams have not only adapted quickly to the challenges before them, but there have embraced a new path forward for Parker and are working hard to build a stronger and better Parker for the future under the direction of the Win Strategy. 
I look forward to sharing more with you on our progress throughout this year. At this time, we're ready to take questions. So Abigail, if you would like to get us started.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016

componenttext: I think -- this is John. I think, James, the pattern is consistent with what we saw during Q2. I think what we're seeing in January is consistent with what we're seeing in guidance. January is, of course -- the first 2 weeks of January are a little bit very difficult to judge. But I think from what we can tell so far that we're consistent with will be -- the guidance that we've got together for Q3. So nothing really remarkable, to give you an answer on there.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it would be, in general, we have good visibility for the OE. And the question is always in the aftermarket. What is included in our guidance is 65% OE, 35% aftermarket. That's what we've been running consistently for the last several quarters. There
componenttext: Well, it would be, in general, we have good visibility for the OE. And the question is always in the aftermarket. What is included in our guidance is 65% OE, 35% aftermarket. That's what we've been running consistently for the last several quarters. There's a little bit of variation periodically, but that's what we're projecting here for the balance of the year.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nicole, this is Lee. Like I've done before in the past,, I'll just kind of walk around the regions, and I'll make some comments on the end markets and I'll also comment on our distribution channel. I think one common thread that hasn't changed is the whol
componenttext: Nicole, this is Lee. Like I've done before in the past,, I'll just kind of walk around the regions, and I'll make some comments on the end markets and I'll also comment on our distribution channel. I think one common thread that hasn't changed is the whole natural resources-driven markets, ag, mining, construction, equipment, oil and gas, they really, by and large, continue to be challenging everywhere around the world. So starting off with North America. I think oil and gas, in terms of distribution, continues to be the big story when you think about distribution in aggregate. Now having said that, if I focus on distribution, it doesn't have heavy continent oil and gas. We've got positive year-over-year growth. But what's happened with oil and gas and its pervasiveness through the distribution base, that is still very difficult. Looking at really air-conditioning, refrigeration markets in North America, we've seen good North American residential air-conditioning growth. This is a result obviously of the continued strengthening of housing market. We've seen share gains on our behalf, and the really increased in product content, which has to do with the sheer efficiency changes that occurred last year. So we're really happy with what's happening in those markets. Commercial air-conditioning refrigeration market really have been down year-over-year, but we are expecting growth in the balance of calendar 2016 and moving into 2017. And then lastly, if I look at the aftermarket channel in this segment, which should be different than the industrial distribution, we really remain solid year-to-date growth. And this is really what -- based on the markets but also a big part of some new products and some smart service toolkit that we've introduced into that market segment, so very positive there. Touching back on North America, oil and gas. As I mentioned in  my distribution comments, we continue to see extreme weakness, double-digit declines across all of our end customers. Our customers, and I've had plenty of these conversations, are not signaling any significant improvement until the end of calendar year '16 or early 2017. All of them have very active restructuring plans to be profitable in today's oil prices. Turning to agriculture. We continue to see top line declines, which is consistent, I think, in contraction and production schedules at our major customers, so very weak on the agricultural equipment side. On energy, wind and energy storage business for us remains robust, with major customers maintaining a healthy backlog. And then the decommissioning of U.S. coal and oil-fired plants continues at a fairly brisk pace and has brought some good opportunity for us on natural gas conversion projects. On heavy-duty truck, Class 8 truck, this market has been very good and growing for us and was excellent. But consistent with industry forecast, we are lowering our forecast by at least 20% from the 2015 levels going forward. On the mobile side, mobile equipment. The traditional construction equipment markets continue to be soft in North America. A highlight here has been some really nice wins in the turf business. The market is up and has been a bright spot as we continue to win new business there. And then lastly, I'll just talk about implant automotive. Our key North American distribution that covers implant automotive is up year-over-year versus Q2 versus prior. But we are expecting a slowing of CapEx spending in this area, which will have an impact on the machine tool builders in this area. So next, North America. In Europe, there's -- well, I'll comment on Europe. So if I talk about distribution, weak overall, with Q2 down versus last year. I think what I have to highlight here is if you pull out distribution, it's tied to oil and gas, which is really U.K., Norway. It's up year-over-year. And we have seen steady progress outside oil and gas-related distribution. We've continued to see strong distribution growth in emerging regions, and this is a highlight. If I look at Germany, it's ahead of last year-to-date. It obviously has much less oil and gas exposure than other countries. Oil and gas for the region, investment in North Sea is almost at a standstill. Looking at the U.K., capital investment in North Sea has dropped significantly. But we are still finding opportunities. We've had some nice wins in point of use for clean diesel wins in some emerging markets, really, systems eliminating high water content using our fluid conveyance and filtration technologies. Agriculture, still pretty much the same as North America. Production rates, low. In energy, very excited about some recent wins for energy grid-type systems and really is a complement to our growth in the renewable energy segments. Class 8 truck, that continues to remain strong. I was looking at this. I think this is the fifth consecutive quarter of growth in that area, so we're very positive about that. And then the mobile construction equipment markets, we actually have seen some stability there with a little bit of modest growth from Q1 to Q2. Turning to Asia. Distribution. As a total, flat to moderately down year-over-year. And I attribute some of that to our continued expansion, which we in highlighted our Win Strategy of expanding our distribution points around the world. And we are doing that in the region. Oil and gas. Again, it is a contraction across the region. It's a note that we do see some positive success with some project builds in China. And I think with a lot of these state-owned oil and gas companies that still continue to invest, maybe it's somewhat of a reduced rate. On energy in the region, really, I'm speaking to China mostly. Renewable, wind, solar and hydro is growing rapidly, but traditional thermal power, coal, is still taking a major share. On rail, and this really speaks to China. We continue to be very bullish on the rail market. The Chinese government's making significant investments in this area. We've had -- there's a strong focus on the export markets, suffice rail technology Europe, Africa and Asia, and they continue to win business there. And for us, we've had a very good market participation in that segment. We continue to have strong participation across the rail market in China. On mobile construction, I can't say anything. It has progressed positively, so last time we talked, there continues to be a slowing rate of growth in China's construction industry and really has been a key driving factor in the deceleration declaration of many parts of the Asia-Pacific. In our customers there continue to have really tons of idle capacity and inventory on hand. And then lastly, just talking to Latin America. It's really about Brazil. I wouldn't go into details. I think everybody knows what was a continued to be just a very dire condition. And we've seen softness in all our end markets, mining, power gen, oil and gas, heavy-duty truck, et cetera.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That was really, really helpful. So just one quick follow-up, if you guys don't mind. So on 3Q, you're guiding for $1.40 EPS at the midpoint. Typically, EPS steps up q-on-q. I know there was some below-line puts and takes between the second quarter that a
componenttext: That was really, really helpful. So just one quick follow-up, if you guys don't mind. So on 3Q, you're guiding for $1.40 EPS at the midpoint. Typically, EPS steps up q-on-q. I know there was some below-line puts and takes between the second quarter that are probably messing up that seasonality a bit. But I'm just curious, are you guys embedding a deterioration in organic growth in 3Q compared to 2Q?

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me start, Nicole. This is Tom, and I'll let Jon and on. What we did for the second half is basically took the order entry that we saw that Lee described in all the regions and markets in the second quarter. What's really -- Aerospace orders got b
componenttext: Yes, let me start, Nicole. This is Tom, and I'll let Jon and on. What we did for the second half is basically took the order entry that we saw that Lee described in all the regions and markets in the second quarter. What's really -- Aerospace orders got better, less negative. And Industrial North America got forced by 3 points, and internationally, of course, by 2. So we took that order entry and basically translated that into the second half from an organic growth standpoint. So our second half organic growth from our previous guidance used to be minus 5, and now it's minus 7.5%. So we dropped the 2.5 points organically. And then we have the second half coming out at a minus 15% decremental MROS, and that's how you get the second half EPS numbers.

Going forward into Q3, our run rate going forward is a 28%, although it's still just slightly higher in our Q3 that we've built in here due to a couple of items that we will account for in the quarter, Eli.

componenttext: Yes. But that 28% versus the 20.3% is sort of like $0.12 to $0.15 or something like, if you consider earnings and that's almost between the 1 52 [ph] and 1 40 [ph] that you're sort of forecasting for us.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016

componenttext: Yes. We are not -- we are down in the topline versus our old guidance in Q3. And we're also down commensurately at the operating income, but like I said, slightly higher rate in Q3 due to some discrete items that we're accounting for in our tax rate there.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And can we talk a little bit about the profitability, the low profitability you're forecasting for the year? Most of that, I assume, is volume. Is there any changes in pricing going on in the marketplace? Will you be able to hold pricing? We as
componenttext: All right. And can we talk a little bit about the profitability, the low profitability you're forecasting for the year? Most of that, I assume, is volume. Is there any changes in pricing going on in the marketplace? Will you be able to hold pricing? We assume cost will continue to trend downward just because of the low input cost. But can you look a little bit towards what's going on in the -- I assume it was a drop in margins that sort of embedded so as drop in this volume-related and rising looks like it's going to be relatively stable in the industry.

componenttext: Eli, this is Lee. I think the drop is all volume-related. Pricing has been flat. We forecast it to be flat going forward.

componenttext: And input cost is still trending downward?

componenttext: A couple of questions related to your guidance. First, if we look back on Q2, can you give us the components of -- there was quite a bit of difference between the initial $1.16 midpoint guidance and the reported $1.52. I understand tax was part of it, but what else changed?

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think at the SG&A level for the quarter, as Tom said, we've got some positive variance in the corporate G&A of about $18 million versus the prior guide. And that's due to the simplification effort and a couple onetime adjustments that won't
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think at the SG&A level for the quarter, as Tom said, we've got some positive variance in the corporate G&A of about $18 million versus the prior guide. And that's due to the simplification effort and a couple onetime adjustments that won't repeat. We've also got, as compared to the prior guide, a small settlement of about $4 million for a contractual issue that we had in the other expense. That's about $4 million, and that accounts for about $0.02. The -- and of course, Eli talk about the tax rate, and we had guided to a higher tax rate. And again, we did know that the extenders was going to pass. And so of course, that turned out to be good news for us. And that gave us $0.15 on the -- versus the prior guide. And then at the operating income level, even with the reduced -- projected reduced revenues, we were able to get approximately $15 million in additional operating income versus the prior guide on a slight beat in revenues.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on that $15 million, is that repeatable? That should carry through going forward.
componenttext: Okay. And then on that $15 million, is that repeatable? That should carry through going forward.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016

componenttext: Yes, that has built into our guidance going forward. And built into our guidance is additional savings that we're going to get from the restructuring efforts that we've been going through the here in the first half of this year and at the end of last year.

But that's not something that we will project in our guidance going forward here. And so I don't really have any context for you on that point.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, a couple of questions. One, I know someone asked before material cost, and you said it was a benefit. But could you quantify what you're assuming for your material cost in your guidance versus when you initially guided? Because I'm just trying to
componenttext: I guess, a couple of questions. One, I know someone asked before material cost, and you said it was a benefit. But could you quantify what you're assuming for your material cost in your guidance versus when you initially guided? Because I'm just trying to understand the decrementals that you guys are putting up, which have been much better than expected. I get that it's simplification initiative and restructuring as well. And then also Tom, if you could just comment on the sustainability of sort of mid- to high-teen decremental margins. We haven't seen that before from Parker. And then my last question is just balance sheet. Given the depressed markets you're seeing, are any -- I know when we spoke last, you said valuations on acquisition was still quite elevated. Has there been any change in the market?

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Jamie, this is Tom. I'll start with the material cost side. I would say, compared to our previous guidance, we're seeing a consistent GAAP between pricing and the materials side, that our ability to maintain the decrementals is driven by the simplif
componenttext: Okay, Jamie, this is Tom. I'll start with the material cost side. I would say, compared to our previous guidance, we're seeing a consistent GAAP between pricing and the materials side, that our ability to maintain the decrementals is driven by the simplification of the restructuring actions. And remember that the bulk of our savings is in the second half, so that is going to help carry us. And we feel good about this fiscal year. I'm not going to go beyond this fiscal year trying to tell you what our large return on sales is going to be. But this fiscal year, we feel very good about sustainability. Return on 3 quarters in a row, and I think for everybody on the phone to help remind everybody, the way we achieved that is it was prior-year restructuring that we did. All the teams are moved out very rapidly to get on top of the market adjustment that we launched the simplification plan, which really was more strategically restructuring leading to the footprint restructuring that we're doing. That enabled us to keep these very nice, basically half of what we have historically have done is a bit of a history lesson. If you go back to the '01 projection, we are -- recession, there's a minus 60% MROS. The Great Recession was around minus 40%. And here we are with minus 15% to minus 20% range on an adjusted basis and low 20s even reported all-in. So I think it's sustainable and that's what we have in the plan for the next 2 quarters. On the balance sheet, the acquisitions -- the pipeline's active, but valuations are still high. And I think what you're seeing is a delay in the reality from sellers expectations to fires like us as far as setting a new revenue targets for what they think for the business. That's the key valuation difference. I think everybody we're disciplined buyers, and we buy things that are in our space. So we understand what the growth rates are. And I think at time's on our side. I think as time goes on, people see the new reality that, hey, it's maybe not going to grow that they had thought. It was the previous decade. But those valuations will come in more online, and I think our pipeline will become were actionable at that point. So it's lumpy. It's hard for us to predict output, but we're still working.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, Tom. One just quick follow-up on the signification initiatives because as you look to 2017, there could be very high profitability that things don't improve or that sales could decline. Based on what you're seeing with sort of the initiatives, do y
componenttext: Sorry, Tom. One just quick follow-up on the signification initiatives because as you look to 2017, there could be very high profitability that things don't improve or that sales could decline. Based on what you're seeing with sort of the initiatives, do you feel that you guys perhaps there's more there to do or you're realizing greater savings than you initially thought that again, the sustainability of the decrementals could -- I mean, could be better than what you originally thought?

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quick, I think that it's possible. I don't want to get above my skis for '17. We'll talk about that in August. But yes, I mean, we've seen for the simplification so far is that the payback is more rapid and has a better payback than traditional restructur
componenttext: Quick, I think that it's possible. I don't want to get above my skis for '17. We'll talk about that in August. But yes, I mean, we've seen for the simplification so far is that the payback is more rapid and has a better payback than traditional restructuring. The good thing about it, just to remind people, there's 4 areas we're looking at, revenue profile complexity so that the deal of the revenue. And we look at the bottom tail, the density of the numbers and the corporate give it is the cost to sustain that. We're very early days in the heading into that. And that a little more typical for us to work with their early days of that. And then the whole organization of process optimization is the second part. We still see lots of opportunities on that. So that's more strategic restructuring overhead structure of the company. The division consolidations was the third leg of it. So we're 28 divisions so far that we're working on. We'll do more. I do think you'll see another 28 in the next fiscal year, what you'll see us continue to work that. And then just good old-fashioned bureaucracy. We're looking at our planning process, approvals, reports, you name it, all of the things that just slows things down, and that obviously carries cost and create better service opportunities for our customers. So early days, and I feel very good about where that -- what this could mean for us. And I think most everybody has seen the walk and taken us to 17% operating margin. Simplification is the biggest bar on the walk. And so I think there's more there.

componenttext: Yes, Joe. This is Tom. Our restructuring year-to-date is right on the money. So we have forecasted 60% of the $100 million, and we have $57 million. And so I'm very confident we're going to deliver both the cost that we have planned, the $100 million of cost, and deliver the savings. And that's -- the savings is indicative of that is larger return on sales. We could not be delivering this kind of returns without actions that we've taken, simplification being one of them that's helping us.

componenttext: Got it. So yes, maybe my numbers are off a little bit in the first half. I'm going to follow up after the call. I was wondering, was there anything onetime, anything special on the stuff in receivables and inventory lying down? Just curious what's driving the stronger free cash flow.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016

componenttext: Jon here, Joe. We are very much focused on the cash flow every single day here in the company. And we're seeing it in the cash flow statement, so we're very proud of that.

componenttext: Nathan, this is Tom. I'll chime in. What we saw in distribution in Q2 was primarily North America because took a step-down. But outside of North America, it held up pretty well. Europe, Asia held up pretty nicely. So the step down in North America was indicative of the same step-down we saw in OEMs, which was a natural resource markets, a little bit of a knock-down in the general industrial space that did not go contribution and the OEMs down. But in general, OEMs have been down about 2x what distribution has been down, if you were to characterize the difference.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that helps. And then with 9 months to go on the original plan for $2 billion to $3 billion of share repurchase, it looks like you're kind of gliding into more of the low end of that. Is that keeping powder dry for some expected correction in the pri
componenttext: Okay, that helps. And then with 9 months to go on the original plan for $2 billion to $3 billion of share repurchase, it looks like you're kind of gliding into more of the low end of that. Is that keeping powder dry for some expected correction in the pricing in the M&A market for you and with an eye to getting perhaps more aggressive as we go forward on M&A?

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nathan, this is Tom. Good question. I'm sure this is on top of everybody's mind. So we feel very good about what we've done so far. Were 87% of the way through the low end of the $2 billion to $3 billion range. And maybe if I could just give a little colo
componenttext: Nathan, this is Tom. Good question. I'm sure this is on top of everybody's mind. So we feel very good about what we've done so far. Were 87% of the way through the low end of the $2 billion to $3 billion range. And maybe if I could just give a little color to the process that we have. Every quarter, we sit down, and it's really cash allocation discussion. We look at cash generation capabilities, what do we think we're going to generate taking a look at that. With the cash generated, what taxes said we have to cash and also with our goal that we'd like to maintain as we go through this for a lot of reasons. But on the deployment side, if we look at the best opportunities to yield the best long-term value for our shareholders comparing, recognizing we're going to do the dividends first. We're not going to move off of that. We're going to find organic growth, but then we're going to look at the balances share repurchase for acquisition just trying to make that best decision. So it's hard for me to give you a specific number that will land on the share repurchase because it's really an opportunistic look weighing those areas tugs and pulls every quarter as we go through that growth model.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And if I could just go off the beaten path a little bit here. You talked about 2Q developing a comprehensive e-business plan and also talked a little bit more about development of the Internet of Things plan. Could you give us a little bit mo
componenttext: Fair enough. And if I could just go off the beaten path a little bit here. You talked about 2Q developing a comprehensive e-business plan and also talked a little bit more about development of the Internet of Things plan. Could you give us a little bit more color on where you are with that, how long the rollout it looks to take and what the benefits will come from that?

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nathan, this is Tom. So I'm going to start with e-business. I'm going to be a little bit coy here with you here because I'm not going to give you the dividend color that I might normally work because I'll be giving competitively sensitive information to o
componenttext: Nathan, this is Tom. So I'm going to start with e-business. I'm going to be a little bit coy here with you here because I'm not going to give you the dividend color that I might normally work because I'll be giving competitively sensitive information to our competitors and trying to help them be successful. But let me just, suffice it to say, that we want on e-business side is we want a Google-like experience for our customers and for our distributors when they come to the website. And we've launched a number of things that we think we'll get us there. It's not going to happen overnight. We've made progress, we think, over the last couple of years. And as we talked our customers and distributors, they see that, but we clearly recognize we're not there. So we see this as a potential additional growth channel leveraging the great distribution channel that we have already. And just remember that about 60% of the relationship between our customers and suppliers nowadays happens to be that website. It happens before we even talk to you. So that's why we want this to be so important. We're investing in it. We made some organizational design changes to add some resources and add leadership because that's what the change we made in August last year. On the Internet of Things, that [indiscernible] place people not familiar with what that is, is basically in aviation process we have gathered ideas around the company. And that coupled with the fact that we make that equity investment in exo site, which gives us a software backbone to help all the applications throughout the company has really given us program for ideas. So we've taken that ideation process to connectathon and we've narrowed it down to about 10 of what we think are the best, most commercial actionable project and we think that's got multimillion-type of look, tens of millions of dollars of revenues over the next 3 years. Most of that's, not going to cut and probably towards the end of FY '17 and FY '18. It's probably going to take 1.5 years incubation here. We do have 2 good examples, and Lee highlighted one of them that the smart service get, which is helping us in refrigeration from the air-conditioning market. So if you take a air-conditioning contract today, they have a lot of mechanical tools they have to do to measure pressure, humidity, temperatures. And so this is a patented sensor that we have, allows you to diagnose and troubleshoot the conditions of that air-conditioning much more rapidly for the value of the contractors. Many more calls happens during the day. They can get a print out be under smartphone or [indiscernible] and pointed out if they wanted for the customer so they can see what's going on with your units. So we launched that. We've been very pleased with the initial sale sand that's really good example of taking a traditional market and using the Internet of Things to make it to be -- to make it even better. It makes our expansion valves and things we get into our check valves very sticky. But in our contract, it's really loved in the toolkit. If you to go to our website, you can probably find a value from one of our contractors testimonial talk about it as well.

componenttextpreview: Well, Andrew, we are constantly trying to make sure that we're producing the right products at the right locations in the right plants. We are not, from a transactional standpoint, getting hurt as bad as we would have been, say, this time last year in ter
componenttext: Well, Andrew, we are constantly trying to make sure that we're producing the right products at the right locations in the right plants. We are not, from a transactional standpoint, getting hurt as bad as we would have been, say, this time last year in terms of the margin. So that is one piece of progress that we've been making. It is not -- that's one of about 10 or 15 things that are going our way that are helping us with our margins and our decrementals. So we don't see that getting bad. We were adjusting. It was this time last year where the euro and the Swiss franc decoupled and also when the dollar was really getting stronger. And so we have adjusted to that where we stand right now today, and that's what's built into our guidance going forward.

I think it's a little bit of a delayed effect as some of those expectations on revenue hasn't come down to earth yet. But I'm on our side. They will come down, and we continue those discussions. And what we see over time is eventually, we'd come to terms with better revenue forecast. We haven't taken action on some deals in the past, managing cost is the difference in pricing and that the pricing difference was primarily cured by differences in what we thought the revenue expectation was going to be for that business.

componenttext: It is going to -- we're structurally going to be down slightly from our past run rate. But it was more of a couple onetime things in the corporate G&A. So it has some structural benefits from the simplification, but there's -- it would be well for me to not mention that there were some onetime items in Q2 for our G&A expense.

componenttext: Joel, it's Tom. The number of divisions that we have operating division's 115. So the 28 is in the 115. So both Lee and I is we're looking for actual combinations that helps us be more efficient, give us the scale that we need to, better across we have some divisions that I think, if we look at in hindsight, have too much technology or product share in overlap and it made more sense to put them together. So it's not going to be one division. We still believe in a decentralized model. We still believe in driving that P&L closer to our team numbers. But I think you're going to continue to see us do more in '17, not at the rate you saw us in '16.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Parker Hannifin Corporation Fiscal 2016 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference ov
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Parker Hannifin Corporation Fiscal 2016 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Chief Financial Officer, Jon Marten. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Abigail, and good morning to everyone, and welcome to Parker Hannifin Second Quarter FY '16 Earnings Release Teleconference. Joining me today is Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Williams; and President and Chief Operating Officer, Le
componenttext:
Thank you, Abigail, and good morning to everyone, and welcome to Parker Hannifin Second Quarter FY '16 Earnings Release Teleconference. 
Joining me today is Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Williams; and President and Chief Operating Officer, Lee Banks. 
Today's presentation slides, together with the audio webcast replay, will be accessible on the company's investor information website at phstock.com for 1 year following today's call. 
On Slide #2, you'll find the company's safe harbor disclosure statement addressing forward-looking statements as well as non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations for any reference to non-GAAP financial measures are included in this morning's press release and are posted on Parker's website at phstock.com. 
On Slide #3, for the agenda. To begin, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Williams, will provide highlights for the second quarter of fiscal year 2016. Following Tom's comments, I will provide a review of the company's second quarter FY '16 performance, together with the revised guidance for FY '16. Tom will provide a few summary comments, and then we'll open the call for a Q&A session. 
At this time, I'll turn it over to Tom and ask that you refer to Slide #4.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jon, and welcome to everyone on the call. We appreciate your participation today. To start, let me make a few summary comments. It continues to be a very tough environment in many of our end markets and regions. We have responded decisively to a
componenttext:
Thanks, Jon, and welcome to everyone on the call. We appreciate your participation today. 
To start, let me make a few summary comments. It continues to be a very tough environment in many of our end markets and regions. We have responded decisively to adjust to these conditions and delivered impressive margin return on sales. We have taken control of discretionary spending, boosted employment levels across our regions in our company and implemented reduced work schedules where necessary. This is in addition to the previously announced actions we have underway to restructure our fixed cost and simplification efforts designed to streamline our operations. On both of those fronts, we made excellent progress in the second quarter. 
Given the current headwinds, we are very pleased with the way our teams have responded, as evidenced by the strong margin performance and our ability to control decremental marginal return on sales for the past 3 quarters. We expect strong decremental marginal return on sales to continue through our fiscal year-end. 
Moving on to specifics for the second quarter. Sales declined 14% as the effects of the strong dollar negatively impacted us by approximately 4%. And organic sales declined 10%, reflecting end market weakness. Total order rates for the second quarter declined 12% compared with the same quarter last year. Despite this downturn, I am very pleased we delivered total segment operating margins of 12.2% or 13.5% on an adjusted basis. 
During the second quarter, we delivered decremental marginal return on sales of 17.2% adjusted, which represents excellent performance in this current business climate. This is really a testament to the way we are fundamentally changing Parker's operating structure. In previous downturns in which we have experienced such a significant reduction in sales volume, we would not have been able to maintain such strong margin performance. 
The primary drivers for our margin performance include savings from restructuring we have done in prior periods, immediate and decisive actions on cost containment and the benefits of a range of simplification initiatives that we have implemented. 
Regarding simplification, we have announced a total of 28 division consolidations. We continue to review our organization and process to reduce overhead costs and simplify processes. This has also helped us to reduce corporate G&A costs. 
Earnings per share for the quarter were $1.33 or $1.52 adjusted for business realignment expenses. Operating cash flow year-to-date includes a $200 million discretionary contribution to the U.S. pension plan. Excluding the contribution year-to-date, operating cash to sales was 9.8%. 
During the second quarter, we repurchased $90 million in Parker shares, bringing our year-to-date total to $400 million. We have now repurchased $1.74 billion under our previously announced $2 billion to $3 billion Parker share repurchase plan over 2 years, which began in October 2014. 
Moving on to the discussion on key market trends. As projected in the second quarter, we saw continued pressure on natural resource markets, such as oil and gas, agriculture, mining and construction equipment, as the prices of commodities continue to move lower. Our distribution channel remain affected by these markets, particularly those with exposure to oil and gas. We continue to experience general industrial activity weakening due to the knock-on effect from natural resource markets. These challenging markets outweighed positive growth in other markets, such as power generation, air conditioning, lawn and turf, rail and heavy-duty truck. 
In summary, our second quarter sales were in line with our October guidance. And Lee will provide some more color on our end markets in the Q&A portion of the call. 
Now switching to our outlook. For fiscal year 2016, we are narrowing the range of our guidance for earnings to $5.90 to $6.30 per share on an adjusted basis, which maintains the earnings midpoint of $6.10 per share. It also means that our implied guidance for the second half of the fiscal year has been adjusted downward for sales and earnings to reflect weaker order entry levels that we experienced in the second quarter. 
We will continue to aggressively manage costs in this challenging environment. Our primary focus will be on maintaining strong decremental margin performance and positioning Parker to weather this downturn and emerge stronger as conditions improve. We are also continuing with actions to execute the many growth opportunities we have identified under the new Win Strategy. 
So just to reinforce, our long-term financial objectives to be achieved by the end of fiscal year 2020 are targeting sales growth of 150 basis points higher than the rate of global industrial production, we are also targeting 17% segment operating margins, and progress towards these goals is expected to deliver a compound annual growth rate in earnings per share of 8% over this 5-year period. 
We are excited about opportunities we have to position Parker as a top-quartile company compared with our proxy peers. 
Growth initiatives are underway to further expand our distribution network, commercialize new products and systems, improve the customer experience, expand our service offerings and to leverage e-business and Internet of Things capabilities. 
During the second quarter, we developed a comprehensive long-term plan to accelerate our e-business capabilities. We see opportunities to leverage our distribution channel as part of our strategy to grow our business and create a better customer experience. 
Parker's Internet of Things initiative gained significant momentum in the quarter. We hosted a global Connectathon that garnered dozens of rich Internet of Things application ideas. 
In summary, execution on the new Win Strategy is expected to deliver top-quartile performance versus our proxy peers. 
So for now, I hand things back to Jon to review more details on the quarter.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. And at this time, please refer to Slide #5. I'll begin by addressing earnings per share for the quarter. Adjusted earnings per share for the second quarter were $1.33 versus $1.80 for the same quarter a year ago. This excludes business real
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. And at this time, please refer to Slide #5. I'll begin by addressing earnings per share for the quarter. 
Adjusted earnings per share for the second quarter were $1.33 versus $1.80 for the same quarter a year ago. This excludes business realignment expenses of $0.19 and compares to $0.04 for the same quarter last year. 
On Slide #6, you'll find the significant components of the walk from adjusted earnings per share of $1.84 for the second quarter FY '15 to $1.52 for the second quarter of this year. The impact of fewer shares outstanding equated to an increase of $0.11 per share. 
Increases to adjusted per share income include lower corporate G&A expense equating to $0.11 due to reduction in long-term incentive accruals as well as our simplification efforts, as Tom mentioned. A reduced tax rate for the quarter contributed $0.02, driven by the passage of the U.S. extenders from which the company recognized R&D credit. Reductions to adjusted per share income include lower adjusted segment operating income of $0.39 per share due to the impact of foreign currency, and the continued weakening of end market demand and increased interest and other expense that totaled $0.18 per share as compared to the prior year in which various onetime favorable loan adjustments were recognized. 
Moving to Slide #7 with a review of the total company sales and segment operating margin for the second quarter. Total company organic sales in the first quarter decreased by 9.6% over the same quarter last year. It was a modest 3% contribution to sales in the quarter from acquisitions. Currency impact as a percentage of sales was slightly higher than planned, equating to a negative impact on reported sales of $139 million or 4.4% in the quarter. 
Total company segment operating margins for the second quarter, adjusted for realignment costs incurred in the quarter, was 13.5% versus 14% for the same quarter last year. Restructuring costs incurred in the quarter were $35 million versus $9 million last year. 
The lower adjusted segment operating income this quarter of $366 million versus $439 million last year reflects the impact of reduced volume and unfavorable mix from the continued weakening of several industrial end markets. 
Moving to Slide #8. I'll discuss the business segments, starting with Diversified Industrial North America. For the second quarter, North American organic sales decreased by 15.2% as compared to the same quarter last year. There was a modest impact from acquisitions and a negative impact from currency of 1.3% in the quarter. 
Operating margin for the second quarter, adjusted for realignment costs, was 15% of sales versus 16.3% in the prior year. Restructuring expenses incurred totaled $20 million as compared to a nominal spend in the prior year. Adjusted operating income was $174 million as compared to $227 million, driven by reduced volume as a result of softening trends in key end markets. 
I'll continue with the Diversified Industrial segment on Slide #9. Organic sales for the second quarter in the Industrial International segment decreased by 7.1%. Currency negatively impacted sales by 10%. Operating margin for the second quarter, adjusted for realignment costs, was 11% of sales versus 12.3% in the prior year. Restructuring expenses incurred in the quarter totaled $14 million as compared to $9 million in the prior year. Adjusted operating income was $109 million as compared to $146 million, which reflects the impact of the foreign currencies as well as weaker end markets. 
I'll now move to Slide #10 to review the Aerospace Systems segment. Organic revenues decreased nominally at 0.7% for the second quarter. Currency posed a modest negative impact of about 0.4%. Sales for the period were maintained as a result of higher aftermarket sales volume, which offset modest year-over-year declines at OEM sales. 
Operating margins for the second quarter, adjusted for realignment costs, was 14.8% of sales versus 12% in the prior year. Nominal realignment expenses were incurred for the period. Adjusted operating income was $82 million as compared to $67 million, reflecting the favorable mix of higher aftermarket sales volume this quarter combined with reduced development costs as a percentage of sales. 
Moving to Slide #11 with the detail of orders changes by segment. As a reminder, Parker orders represent a trailing average and are reported as a percentage increase of absolute dollars year-over-year, excluding acquisitions, divestitures and currency. The Diversified Industrial segments report on a 3-month rolling average while Aerospace Systems are based on a 12-month rolling average. 
Total orders were a negative 12% for the quarter end, reflecting the further softening of the Industrial segment stemming from natural resource-related end markets, as Tom mentioned. Diversified Industrial North American orders decreased to negative 15%. Diversified Industrial International orders decreased to negative 10% for the quarter. Aerospace Systems orders improved to a negative 11% for the quarter, which continues to be impacted by lumpy prior year comparables. 
On Slide #12, we report cash flow from operations. Cash flow from operating activities year-to-date was $347 million, but when adjusted for the $200 million discretionary pension contribution made in the first quarter, cash from operating activities was 9.8% of sales. This compares to 8.4% of sales for the same period last year. 
In addition to the pension contribution, the significant uses of cash year-to-date were $572 million returned to our shareholders via share repurchases of $400 million and dividends of $172 million. $68 million was expended for acquisitions closed during the first quarter. No acquisitions were announced in the second quarter. And we had $75 million for CapEx, equating to approximately 1.4% of sales year-to-date. 
Slide #13 provides the -- for FY '16 guidance as outlined. Guidance is being provided on an adjusted basis. Segment operating margins and earnings per share exclude expected business realignment charges of approximately $100 million, which are forecast to be incurred throughout FY '16. 
Total sales are expected to be in the range of negative 12.6% to negative 9.3% or negative 9.9% at the midpoint as compared to the prior year. Adjusted organic growth at the midpoint is negative 7.9%. Currency in the guidance negatively impacts sales by 3.4%, which is nearly all attributable to the International Industrial segment. We have calculated the impact of currency to spot rates as of December 31, 2015, and we have held those rates steady as we estimate the resulting year-over-year impact for the balance of FY '16. 
For total Parker, adjusted segment operating margins are forecast to be between 14.4% and 14.6%. This compares to 14.9% for FY '15 on an adjusted basis. As Tom mentioned, we are very pleased to be guiding to this level of adjusted segment operating margins given the magnitude of the end market softness and order decline. 
The guidance for below-the-line items, which includes corporate admin, interest and our category, other, is 440 -- $484 million for the year at the midpoint. Our full year tax rate is projected at approximately 28%. The average number of fully diluted shares outstanding used in the full year guidance is 137.1 million shares. 
For the full year, guidance on an adjusted earnings per share basis is $5.90 to $6.30 or $6.10 at the midpoint. This guidance excludes business realignment expenses of approximately $100 million to be incurred in FY '16. Savings from these business realignment initiatives continue to be projected in the amount of $70 million, which are reflected in the segment operating margins. 
Some additional key assumptions for full year 2016 guidance are sales are divided 49% first half, 51% second half. Adjusted segment operating income is divided 49% first half, 51% second half. Adjusted EPS is $3.04 in the first half and $3.06 in the second half. Q3 FY '16 adjusted earnings per share is projected to be $1.40 per share at the midpoint, and this excludes $0.17 of business realignment expenses. 
On Slide #14, you'll find a reconciliation of the major components of the revised FY '16 adjusted EPS guidance of $6.10 per share at the midpoint from the prior FY '16 EPS guidance. Increases include $0.12 from reduced tax rate; $0.13 from a reduced corporate G&A, interest and other; and $0.05 from fewer shares outstanding. This is fully offset by a decrease of $0.30 reduction in segment operating income, reflecting further reduced volume and unfavorable mix forecasted within key industrial end markets. 
Please remember that the forecast excludes any future acquisitions or divestitures that might be closed during FY '16. For consistency, we ask that you exclude restructuring expenses from your published estimates. 
This concludes my prepared comments. Tom, I'll turn the call back to you for your summary comments.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jon. We expect the difficult environment to continue through the rest of our fiscal year. As our margins year-to-date indicate, we are responding well. We are making meaningful progress with our restructuring initiatives, which remain on track for
componenttext:
Thanks, Jon. We expect the difficult environment to continue through the rest of our fiscal year. As our margins year-to-date indicate, we are responding well. We are making meaningful progress with our restructuring initiatives, which remain on track for the year. We also continue to find opportunities to streamline operations through our simplification initiatives. 
I am very encouraged by the response of our Parker team members. It has been just about 1 year since Lee and I took full responsibility for the company. It's certainly been a challenging year from a market perspective. However, our teams have not only adapted quickly to the challenges before them, but they have also embraced the new path forward for Parker and are working hard to build a stronger and better Parker for the future under the direction of the Win Strategy. 
I look forward to sharing more with you on our progress throughout this year. At this time, we're ready to take questions. So Abigail, if you would like to get us started.

componenttextpreview: Well, it would be -- in general, we have good visibility for the OE. And the question is always in the aftermarket. What is included in our guidance is 65% OE, 35% aftermarket. That's what we've been running consistently for the last several quarters. The
componenttext: Well, it would be -- in general, we have good visibility for the OE. And the question is always in the aftermarket. What is included in our guidance is 65% OE, 35% aftermarket. That's what we've been running consistently for the last several quarters. There's a little bit of variation periodically, but that's what we're projecting here for the balance of the year.
