headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Parker Hannifin Corp. Quarter 3 2016  Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. Now I will hand the floor over to Jon Marten, Chief Financial Off
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Parker Hannifin Corp. Quarter 3 2016  Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]
As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. Now I will hand the floor over to Jon Marten, Chief Financial Officer. Sir, you have the floor.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Parker Hannifin's Third Quarter FY '16 Earnings Release Teleconference. Joining me today is Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Williams; and President and Chief Operating Officer, Lee Banks. Today's presentation slide
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Parker Hannifin's Third Quarter FY '16 Earnings Release Teleconference. Joining me today is Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Williams; and President and Chief Operating Officer, Lee Banks. 
Today's presentation slides, together with the audio webcast replay, will be accessible on the company's investor information website at phstock.com for 1 year following today's call. 
On Slide #2, you'll find the company's safe harbor disclosure statement addressing forward-looking statements as well as non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations for any reference to non-GAAP financial measures are included in this morning's press release and are posted on Parker's website at phstock.com.
Today's call agenda appears on Slide #3. To begin, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Williams, will provide highlights of the third quarter of fiscal year '16. Following Tom's comments, I will provide a review of the company's third quarter FY 2016 performance, together with the revised guidance for FY 2016. Tom will provide a few summary comments, and then we'll open the call for Q&A. 
At this time, I'll turn it over to Tom and ask that you refer to Slide #4.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jon. Good morning, and welcome to everyone on the call. We appreciate your participation. So today, we're going to cover 4 key topics with you. First, I'll summarize the third quarter results; second, some commentary on key market trends; give you
componenttext:
Thanks, Jon. Good morning, and welcome to everyone on the call. We appreciate your participation. So today, we're going to cover 4 key topics with you. First, I'll summarize the third quarter results; second, some commentary on key market trends; give you an update on the revised full year guidance; and finally, I'll highlight some of the progress we're making on the key initiatives of the Win Strategy. 
So beginning with the third quarter results. Sales declined 10.6%, as the effects of the strong dollar negatively impacted us by 1.5%, and organic sales declined approximately 9.4%. Total order rates for the third quarter declined 6% compared with the same quarter last year. This is a sequential improvement from the second quarter. 
Earnings per share for the quarter were $1.37 or $1.51, adjusted for business realignment, which was ahead of our expectations. Operating cash flow year-to-date includes a $200 million discretionary contribution to the U.S. pension plan. Excluding the contribution year-to-date, operating cash to sales was 10.5%. 
During the second quarter, we repurchased $50 million in shares, bringing our year-to-date total to $450 million. We have now repurchased $1.8 billion of shares since October 2014. 
However, the most impressive accomplishment of the third quarter was our margin performance. I am very pleased we delivered total segment operating margins of 13.8% or 14.7% on an adjusted basis. This represents a 30 basis point improvement year-over-year in adjusted margins, which is a significant complement, given the difficult economic conditions we are facing. 
During the third quarter, we delivered decremental margin return on sales of 17% or 11.8%, adjusted for business realignment expenses. This demonstrates excellent performance by our global team. 
This quarter marks the fifth consecutive quarter with decremental MRO less of less than 30%. This is both on a reported and an adjusted basis. Year-to-date, we have also held SG&A flat at 12.1% of sales, despite a $1.2 billion drop in sales, another significant accomplishments by our team. 
Our performance during such a sustained period of lower sales and order rates is unprecedented. It demonstrates Parker's ability to create a more adaptable cost structure and deliver a less cyclical financial performance. 
So now a few brief comments on key end markets. So reflecting on order rates over the past year, we're encouraged the point of moderating decline. More specifically, from Q2 to Q3, we saw a number of end markets moving from what we'd classify as accelerating decline to a decelerating decline, which is a good sign. We will continue to monitor additional data points in the coming months to help solidify our interpretation of the direction of the macroeconomic trends and provide you an update on our August call. 
As usual, I'll provide more detail on our specific and markets during the Q&A portion of this call. 
Switching to the outlook. For fiscal year 2016, we are increasing our guidance for earnings to the range of $6.20 to $6.40 per share on an adjusted basis, which results in an earnings mid-point of $6.30 per share. Adjusted guidance represents a $0.20 increase from our previous estimate at the mid-point. The increase can be attributed to the third quarter beat and incremental savings we are now seeing from the realignment actions we've taken year-to-date. 
We also now anticipate higher business realignment expenses, which, for the full year, will go from $100 million to $120 million or $0.63 per share. 
As we have moved deeper into the new Win Strategy initiatives, our global teams [indiscernible] additional near-term actions that will generate attractive return on investment. 
These actions will position us well for future growth and profitability.
Now I'd like to give you some highlights from the new Win Strategy. We continue to make meaningful progress with our Win Strategy initiatives to increase the member engagement, deliver premier customer experience and drive overall growth and financial performance. 
Take a moment to update you on progress in a couple of select areas. Starting with safety. We have seen a 29% reduction in our reportable injuries compared to the third quarter of fiscal 2016 with the same period a year ago on a rolling 12-month basis. This reflects safety engagement across the organization and the progress of our safety-focused, high-performance teams. Our goal is to reach 0 accidents. The significance for our shareholders is that safe operations are productive operations, which translate to excellent financial results. 
Our simplification initiative is gaining tremendous momentum throughout the organization. It focuses on 4 key areas: revenue complexity, organizational structure and processes, division consolidations and bureaucracy. It's a strategic review of our overhead but also a strategic review of our organization process and to improve our customers experience in Parker and also to drive growth. I'll give you a few examples of that. 
Our division consolidations have yielded cost savings and will generate technology and products for future growth. Our sales force organization redesign providing more effective alignment between our customers, distributors and divisions. 
And another example, normally at this same of year, we are working through an extensive annual planning process. This year, we greatly simplified that process and dramatically reduce amount of time that goes into the developing our annual plan. What used to take 5 months now takes 8 weeks. In August, we will share the outlook for this process and form of our guidance for fiscal year 2017. 
Innovation activity continues to be strong and will position us well when the macro conditions stabilize. I'll give you 3 examples on the innovation front. Several years ago, we've commercialized a series of conductive gels that helped cool delicate, electronic components in mobile devices and automotive applications such as collision avoidance. That product series continues to do well for us today in these fast-growing markets. 
Turning to the third quarter, we were particularly pleased to receive FDA approval of our groundbreaking exoskeleton technology, Indego. Indego was approved for clinical and personal use by individuals with spinal cord injury, which allows them to walk again. With approvals now in the U.S. and Europe, we're positioned for full commercial launch of Indego. Markedly, we went from an idea to launch in less than 3 years already generating initial sales in FY 2016. 
Planned for launch next year as a CNG fuel regular a modular, which optimizes fuel emissions for Class 5 to 8 trucks. This module is a one-piece design and integrates multiple products into a central compact system, we're optimistic about the commercial [indiscernible] important product. 
These examples that showcase just some of the highlights from the past, present and future innovations that create vitality and growth for new products and technologies. 
So in summary, by executing the new Win Strategy, we are confident we will achieve our key financial objectives by the end of fiscal 2020, which includes targeted sales growth of 150 basis points higher than the rate of global industrial production. We're also targeting 17% segment operating margins. And progress towards these goals is expected to drive a compound annual growth rate in earnings per share of 8% over this 5-year period. 
I am very pleased at how far we have come in such a short period of time and continue to be excited about the opportunities we have for the future, as we strive to make Parker a top-quartile company as compared to our proxy peers. 
So for now I'll hand things back to Jon to review more detail s on the quarter.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. And at this time, please refer to Slide #5. I'll begin by addressing earnings per share for the quarter. Adjusted earnings per share for the quarter were $1.51 versus $2.06 for the same quarter a year ago. This excludes business realignment
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. And at this time, please refer to Slide #5. I'll begin by addressing earnings per share for the quarter. 
Adjusted earnings per share for the quarter were $1.51 versus $2.06 for the same quarter a year ago. This excludes business realignment expenses of $0.14 and compares to $0.04 for the same quarter last year.
On to Slide #6, you'll find the significant components of the walk from adjusted earnings per share of $2.06 for the third quarter FY '15 to $1.51 for the third quarter of this year. 
Increases to adjusted per share income include the impact of fewer shares outstanding equating to an increase of $0.05 [ph] per share and lower corporate G&A and interest expense equating to $0.04 due to reduction of long-term incentive accruals and our simplification efforts. 
Reductions to adjusted income per share income include increased other expense that totals $0.33 per share as compared to the prior year, in which, last year, sizable onetime favorable currency adjustments were recognized, lower adjustment segment operating income of $0.21 per share due to the impact of the weakened markets and $0.10 from an increased effective tax rate, driven by various discrete items booked in the quarter.
Moving to Slide #7. With the reveal of total company sales and segment operating margin for the third quarter, total company organic sales in the third quarter decreased by 9.4% over the same quarter last year. There was a 3% contribution to sales in the quarter from acquisitions. Currency impact as a percentage of sales was relatively in line with our guidance, equating to a negative impact on reported sales of 1.5% in the quarter. 
Total company segment operating margin for the third quarter, adjusted for realignment costs incurred in the quarter, was 14.7% versus 14.4% for the same quarter last year. We are especially pleased with this performance, given the end market softness. 
Realignment costs incurred in the quarter were $25 million versus $8 million last year. As forecast previously, the lower adjusted segment operating income this quarter of $417 million versus $456 million last year reflects the impact of the reduced volume and the unfavorable mix from the weakening of industrial end markets.
Moving to Slide #8. I'll discuss the business segments, starting with Diversified Industrial North America. For the third quarter, North American organic sales decreased by 12.7% as compared to the same quarter last year. There was a modest impact from acquisitions and a negative impact of currency of 0.8% in the quarter. Operating margin for the third quarter, adjusted for realignment costs, was an impressive 16.9% of sales versus 16.4% in the prior year. 
Realignment expenses incurred totaled $9 million as compared to $1 million in the prior year. Adjusted operating income was $211 million as compared to $237 million, driven by reduced volume as a result of the weakening in our key end markets.
On Slide #9, I'll continue with the Diversified Industrial segment on this slide. Organic sales for the third quarter in the industrial international segment decreased by 8.7%. Currency negatively impacted sales by 3.1%. Operating margin for the third quarter, adjusted for realignment costs, was 11.9% of sales versus 12.7% in the prior year. Realignment expenses incurred in the quarter totaled $16 million as compared to $7 million in the prior year. Adjusted operating income was $121 million as compared to $146 million, which reflects the impact of weaker end markets.
I'll now move to Slide # 10 to review the Aerospace Systems segment. Organic revenues decreased 2% for the quarter. Currency impact was negligible. Sales for the period was impacted by some softness in helicopter and business jets. 
Operating margin for the third quarter, adjusted for realignment costs, was 15.1% of sales versus 12.9% in the prior year. Adjusted operating income was $85 million as compared to $74 million last year, reflecting combination of higher aftermarket sales volume mix, reduced development costs as a percent of sales and implementation of the new Win Strategy.
Moving to Slide #11 with the detail of orders changes by segment as. A reminder, Parker orders represent a trailing average and are reported as a percentage increase of absolute dollars year-over-year, excluding acquisitions, divestitures and currency. The Diversified Industrial segment report on a 3-month rolling average, while Aerospace Systems are based on a 12-month rolling average. Total orders were a negative 6% for the quarter end, reflecting less negative order rates in Industrial segments and Aerospace segment, order is turning positive. Diversified Industrial North American orders improved to negative 9. 
Diversified industrial international orders improved to negative 6 for the quarter. Aerospace System orders improved to a positive 1 for the quarter. 
Now turning to Slide # 12 on cash flow. Cash flow from operating activities year-to-date was $681 million. When adjusted for the $200 million discretionary pension contribution made in the first quarter, cash from operating activities was $881 million or 10.5% of sales. This compares to 8.3% of sales for the same period last year. 
In addition to the pension contribution discussed earlier, the significant uses of cash year-to-date were $707 million returned to our shareholders via share repurchases and dividends; $68 million for acquisitions closed during Q1. No acquisitions were announced in Q3. $111 million for CapEx equating to 1.3% of sales year-to-date.
The revised full year earnings guidance for FY '16 is outlined on Slide # 13. Guidance is being provided on an adjusted basis. Segment operating margins and earnings per share exclude expected business realignment charges of approximately $120 million, the balance of which are forecast to be incurred in Q4 of FY '16. 
Total sales are expected to be in the range of negative 11.9% to negative 9.9% or negative 10.9% at the mid-point as compared to last year. 
Adjusted organic growth at the mid-point is negative 8.2. Currency in the guidance negatively impacts sales by 3, the majority of which is attributed to the Industrial International segment. We have calculated the impact of currency to spot rates as of March 31, 2016. And we have held those rates steady as we estimate the resulting year-over-year impact for the balance of '16.
The total Parker adjusted segment operating margins are forecast to be between 14.7% and 14.9% or 14.8% at the mid-point. This compares to 14.9% for FY '15 on an adjusted basis. As Tom mentioned, we are very pleased to be guiding to this level of adjusted segment operating margins, given the magnitude of the end market declines. 
The guidance for below-the-line items, which includes corporate admin, interest and other is $478 million for the year to the mid-point. The full year tax rate is projected at approximately 28%. The average number of fully diluted shares outstanding used in our full year guidance is 137 million. 
And for the full year, guidance on an adjusted earnings per share basis has been increased to $6.20 to $6.40 or $6.30 at the mid-point. The guidance excludes business realignment expenses of approximately $120 million to be incurred in FY '16. Savings for these business realignment initiatives are projected in the amount of $85 million, which are reflected in the segment operating margins. 
Slide #14, you'll find a reconciliation of major components of the revised FY '16 as reported EPS guidance of $5.67 per share at the mid-point from the prior FY '16 EPS of $5.60 per share. Increases include $0.18 in segment operating income as a result of simplification efforts and increased savings from restructuring actions taken a day and $0.08 from reduced corporate G&A, interest share and share; the company's decision to increase full year realignment cost to $120 million, resulting in an additional expense of $0.13 per share. Income taxes and other expense projected comprise additional expense of $0.06, reflecting discrete items in current projections. 
On Slide #15, you'll find a reconciliation of the major components of the revised FY '16 adjusted EPS guidance of $6.30 per share at the mid-point from prior FY '16 EPS of $6.10. As previously detailed, increases include $0.18 in segment operating income and $0.08 from reduced corporate G&A, interest and share count. This is partially offset by $0.06 increase in other expense and taxes. 
Please remember that the forecast excludes any future acquisitions, divestitures that might be closed during FY '16. 
For consistency's purposes, we ask that you exclude restructuring expenses from your published estimates. 
This concludes my prepared comments. Tom, I'll turn the call back to you for your summary comments.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. I'm very encouraged by the response of our Parker team members around the world. We are weathering the challenges of our end markets and delivering impressive moments. Team and pricing changes designed to improve Parker and position us for t
componenttext:
Thanks, John. I'm very encouraged by the response of our Parker team members around the world. We are weathering the challenges of our end markets and delivering impressive moments. Team and pricing changes designed to improve Parker and position us for the future under the framework of the new Win Strategy. 
Together, we are building a stronger and better Parker. I look forward to sharing more with you on our Parker. At this time, we're ready to take questions. So Brian, if you could get us started.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Jamie Cook from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Jamie Cook from Credit Suisse.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess a couple of questions. One, Tom, I guess everyone's interested in sort of the order of sales trends that you saw throughout the first quarter and potentially what you're seeing in the month of April. Are there any markets that you sort of see bott
componenttext: I guess a couple of questions. One, Tom, I guess everyone's interested in sort of the order of sales trends that you saw throughout the first quarter and potentially what you're seeing in the month of April. Are there any markets that you sort of see bottoming or perhaps even seen seeing green shoots without being too optimistic? And then, I guess, just my second question to you is with one quarter left within the year, you upped your restructuring again. As we're thinking about 2017, do we think we've done enough to restructuring, given your view on the markets, that this should be -- we just have to execute on what's already out there? Or could there be potential for more as we think about 2017?

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Jamie. This is Tom. So I'll start first with order trends. So orders during the quarter sequentially got better, as we saw January through March. I see what we saw in April, it's consistent with the guidance that we gave you. As far as the markets g
componenttext: Okay, Jamie. This is Tom. So I'll start first with order trends. So orders during the quarter sequentially got better, as we saw January through March. I see what we saw in April, it's consistent with the guidance that we gave you. As far as the markets go, I'll finish all my comments. I'll let Lee you some deeper color. But I made a comment about we saw a number of markets move from accelerating decline to decelerating decline. So I think the theme of what you're seeing as this moderation of decline. And the movers from accelerating to decelerating correlates lead to charge for distribution and general industrial, ag, mining and semicon. And he asked for some of the positive markets, positive markets are refrigeration and air-conditioning, rail, turf, aerospace, commercial, MRO and power gen. And I'll let Lee go into more details here in a minute on all the market color. On the restructuring, we moved from $100 million to $120 million. And just to clear the air with people listening on the phone, this isn't because we saw some market change or worsening of orders that we felt we needed to do this. Really was we saw more opportunities as you start to peel the new Win Strategy being implemented within the company. Just more opportunities that the team members around the world to identify and traditional restructuring and simplification, et cetera, that we thought would be very good to take now and that will put us in a good position in FY '17. But you asked about '17 now. In my opening comments, talked about your moves us to an 8-week process, 3 weeks into it, so I won't comment about 17, as you might imagine going about '17 in April. It's even harder to commenting about it in August. However, I will give us some color on the restructuring. So restructuring this year is, I would call, a high water market, $120 million. And if you look at the traditional before kind of the restructuring we've done in the last several years, we're more $20 million to $25 million range. Now while the restructuring is not finalized for what we think year and rolling about halfway through reviews, I think we're looking at something that's in between the traditional $20 million to $25 million and the $120 million that we did this year. So that's my take in your comments, Jamie. If it's okay, I'll let Lee take over with giving you a lot more color on the markets, which I'm sure other people will have questions on as well.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Hi, Jamie. So as Tom talked about, sequentially, total Parker organic growth moved to a better direction during the quarter. If you look at it, it was largely a result of North America, followed by EMEA. I'm going to walk you through the different r
componenttext: Okay. Hi, Jamie. So as Tom talked about, sequentially, total Parker organic growth moved to a better direction during the quarter. If you look at it, it was largely a result of North America, followed by EMEA. I'm going to walk you through the different regions and try to give you as much color as I can. So starting with North America, industrial distribution. Total North American distribution still is annualizing at a high single-digit year-over-year decline for FY '16. Now this is mostly, as we talked about in the past, impacted by oil and gas. So we continue to see tightening of CapEx and OpEx budgets, which has really been a drag for distribution. It's most aligned with those end markets. If you get away from that, we continue to see real positive growth out of distribution in the Great Lakes, Midwest areas and cover auto plants Tier 1 machine builders, et cetera. So it's a couple of different tales, depend on where you are in the country. Tom mentioned air conditioning and refrigeration. That's really a bright spot for us. We continue to experience really strong residential air conditioning growth. Much of that growth can be attributed to some product introductions, as we've done. It's really giving us a strong market participation. Commercial air conditioner refrigeration business is up low single digits, and our aftermarket business, organically with the market and some new product introductions. So that continues to be real strong. The story around oil and gas, I guess, major OEMs really continue to indicate no significant improvement until the end of calendar 2016, early 2017. And really massive, and I'm sure you've covered this, restructuring plans taking place. So looks like everybody's trying to restructure and work to be profitable around $40 per barrel. And we look at some of those different segments, the consensus appears that really the offshore rig market for new builds can take years to recover. I think the land base will come back sooner. But on the positive side, you've heard us talk about this. We continue to increase demand for solar aftermarket service capabilities such as Parker tracking system that enables asset integrity management in the field. We've had a good traction with that. On agriculture, we expect sales and farm equipment down industry-wide, and our demand continues to be consistent with that. I'm focusing on energy. We continue to increase our market position with a large frame term OEMs, and this has been a plus because there's been a -- continues to be a strong conversion of power plants from coal to natural gas in the U.S. So it's a lot of us to participate in. And we did see benefits from our wind and solar business to get a boost from the production tax credits and investment tax grants that were extended. So that was a positive for us in the quarter. Turning to heavy truck in North America. Current forecast, ACT forecast is now 275,000 units, which is really up from the November forecast. And our North America transportation business is down high single digits, better than industry build rate declines. And I would attribute this to some product introductions and really our aftermarket exposure here, kind of softens some of that downturn. On the mobile markets, I think a real positive. Tom mentioned Turf. It's a North American central market but continues to be real strong highlight for us. And then with all the major construction equipment that continues to experience topline declines. But there doesn't seem to be a lot of industry commentary about finding a bottom here, which I'll comment more later on. And then plant automotive, really, this is a key North American distribution that covers that. We're up Q3 versus prior and continue to do well there. Just touching on Europe. Distribution, trends are consistent with [indiscernible] last quarter. Distribution tied to industrial MRO. Automotive markets continue to be flat to slightly positive. And then anything tied to oil and gas, as I mentioned before, continues to be weak. I think one of the bright spots for us really contained in our Win Strategy initiative is distribution is up in emerging markets, Eastern Europe, Africa. These are high single digits, a combination of organic growth within the region but plus a fact of increased market participation by us. Oil and gas, demand across all those related markets continue to contract. We've talked about North Sea investment, and that really is still at a standstill. But then again, this is another area where we've had sort of really decent experience with our aftermarket integrity management initiatives offsetting some of the contraction that we see at our first field level. And then on ag, we have seen sequential growth quarter-to-quarter. Still flat year-over-year, but the production we're seeing now, I'll call it, increased normal seasonality. On heavy truck, stronger demand continues in the quarter, and this is really following a strong fiscal Q2. We saw demand sequentially from Q2 to Q3. And mobile, demand has stabilized at current activity level. We did have an art exhibit at the recent [indiscernible] Show, and I think all of us were encouraged by, one, the attendance, but also the favorable sentiment taking place at the show. So maybe it guys creates this positive going forward. Turning to Asia now. Really, distribution then is flat to moderately down year-over-year. China is the biggest issue. It's the most sluggish. It's down high single digits year-over-year. If I take that out, we're up across the region. I give this a lot of credit to what our guys are doing, expansion that we talked to you about such as ASEAN and some of these developing markets. So we continue to expand there. Energy across the region, we still see increased activity  in renewable, which wind, solar and hydro and traditional thermal energy, coal gas and nuclear still taking a major share and participating in the numbers. Rail, we've talked about talk some accelerating growth. Continues to be a great story. Sometime on the strength of this market in China. And China has really become a preferred builder. We recently signed high-speed rail contracts with [indiscernible] Indonesia. And we continue to have strong exposure [indiscernible] build rates. And that in mobile construction, where we see some modest growth in China. And I heard some industry comments regarding that. I will tell you that in the most part, the OEM inventory still extremely high. So I think it'll take some time for us to see that, but our business has stabilized at current levels. And then lastly, just touching on Latin America. I think it's really dominated by the Brazil story. Construction equipment, ag markets, et cetera, still very soft. But there is decent activity if you get outside of Brazil, but the whole story in Latin America is really brought by Brazil. So taken all together, total Parker organic growth sequentially moved in a better direction, largely as a result, as I mentioned. North America and EMEA. And I think moderately declining coming to our minds scrambled you're seeing out of a year-over-year basis.

componenttext: I guess my first question is around the restructuring actions. I know it's hard to comment much at this point on 2017, but it seems like the babe equity got on these actions, the additional realignment actions is really good. I guess, my question is how are you thinking about -- when you're thinking about the magnitude of restructuring for next year, how are you think about the potential payback? And is it going to be mostly headcount related?

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joe, this Tom. So on the restructuring, I would just say, in general, we're really pleased with our team, team around the world. Execution has been timely. We've been thoughtful how we've done it. And I'm just very proud of how the team has performed on t
componenttext: Joe, this Tom. So on the restructuring, I would just say, in general, we're really pleased with our team, team around the world. Execution has been timely. We've been thoughtful how we've done it. And I'm just very proud of how the team has performed on the restructuring. And that's been a big part of the -- timeliness of that has been a big part of what's helping our margins perform this year. As far as next year, we're still going through it. I still think my characterization of being somewhere between $120 million, and the 20 to 25 is probably a good indicator. I still think that, for the most part, this restructuring is pretty good payback from a timing standpoint. Usually, 12-month indicator, obviously some are more traditional or international orientating type of restructuring will take longer, probably 18 to 24 months. But in general, it would still be aimed at the more strategic restructuring we've been talking about, which is at -- we're ahead of the company. But we'll continue to look at it as we traditionally have, the footprint optimization. As it makes sense.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And maybe as a follow-up. Tom, your comments earlier about going from an accelerating to decelerating decline. I'm just curious within that context, what's going on with the pricing environment? Are you seeing any pressure across the portfolio today? Have you started to see stabilization there as well? Just curious. Any color there would be helpful.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Joe, this is Lee. I'll just give you some comments on that. So I would characterize pricing realization is very tough, candidly. We did raise prices to distribution this past January. It was mostly around noncore and late life cycle type products. We did
componenttext: Joe, this is Lee. I'll just give you some comments on that. So I would characterize pricing realization is very tough, candidly. We did raise prices to distribution this past January. It was mostly around noncore and late life cycle type products. We did realized pricing there. But one thing we do track, and you've heard us talk about this in the past, we have an STI index, which tracks year-over-year pricing by partner. We have a PPI, which tracks our input costs. And we do have a positive spread. When we look at the continues. So I will say if you had to characterize it overall, it's pretty much flat.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Lee, is that spread mostly being driven by the denominator? So is it just because that the cost environment has remained favorable? And could that position be reversed the toughest we progress through the year?
componenttext: And Lee, is that spread mostly being driven by the denominator? So is it just because that the cost environment has remained favorable? And could that position be reversed the toughest we progress through the year?

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say the top line, the SPI number is flat, as I talked about, but the PPI has given us a spread, I guess.
componenttext: I would say the top line, the SPI number is flat, as I talked about, but the PPI has given us a spread, I guess.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the buyback. It looks like it's slowed here a little bit. M&A has kind of been a week. I just thought, as  we kind of come on the deadline for this $2 billion to $3 billion would be tracking more towards the high end. Maybe just update us on how y
componenttext: Just on the buyback. It looks like it's slowed here a little bit. M&A has kind of been a week. I just thought, as  we kind of come on the deadline for this $2 billion to $3 billion would be tracking more towards the high end. Maybe just update us on how you're thinking about buyback.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeff. This is Tom. So on the buyback, we continue to look at that on a dynamic basis, looking what and what makes sense most sense for our shareholders. And obviously, we'll update you every quarter on that. But some things just keep in mind and cons
componenttext: Yes, Jeff. This is Tom. So on the buyback, we continue to look at that on a dynamic basis, looking what and what makes sense most sense for our shareholders. And obviously, we'll update you every quarter on that. But some things just keep in mind and consideration. When you look at our cash that's on the balance sheet, 99% of that is permanently invested overseas. We also -- it's important to us to maintain our A rating, so that's a factor that we consider. And then when we rolled out $2 billion to $3 billion initiative, that was in October 2014, we were a $13 billion company then, and that were $11.3 billion. So a number of things have changed. Our cash flow as a percent of sales continue to do very well at 10.5%. We're going to continue to deploy cash as efficiently as we can. We look at the best ways to deploy it and what gives the long-term value creation to our shareholders. On the acquisition side, the pipeline is active. But it's always hard to predict the output there. So it tends to be lumpy. But I would say valuations are still challenging at this point, with pricing probably starting to moderate a little bit. But we are disciplined buyers and we buy things that are in space. We understand the growth rate so we'll continue to be that way. But I think you'll look to see us be as efficient and aggressive with our deployment  of cash as we possibly can, bring all the variables the best we can on long-term behalf of shareholders.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then it looks like the guidance is mostly North America feeling a little bit better. And I think you mentioned some of the restructuring. But just going to a little more detail on what's surprising you to the upside in the North
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then it looks like the guidance is mostly North America feeling a little bit better. And I think you mentioned some of the restructuring. But just going to a little more detail on what's surprising you to the upside in the North America business.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Jeff, I think Lee did a good job of taking you through that. In North America, when you look at it sequentially, most everything was possible in North America. Some of that would just get from the calendar helping us. But in particular, the part tha
componenttext: Well, Jeff, I think Lee did a good job of taking you through that. In North America, when you look at it sequentially, most everything was possible in North America. Some of that would just get from the calendar helping us. But in particular, the part that I like is that when you look at -- people don't understand what I'm talking about. These marketplaces, see that accelerating growth and decelerating growth, and you got accelerating decline and decelerating decline. I was about to show you this dot map of our end markets in these 4 phases. And you look at it in Q2, you'd see a lot of dots is accelerate decline. And what's moved, and I would say in particular, North America, it's been distribution, ag, semicon, mining, general industrial. But I think the thing that we're still cautious about is that I think we're getting help from comps for the most part. And at this point, still too early I think to see that there's a general market shift. So we're going to continue to look at that data. We need a few more months and another quarter to help confirm that. On the healing process of order entry, step one, is to have a decelerating or moderation of decline. So that's a good thing. We're very happy about that. And to put of the kind of numbers we're putting up on this kind of climate, I think if you look at historic always remarkable. And of told a lot of people when we get to flat, you're going to love the numbers because that will be the new high. And then we'll continue to grow from there.

componenttext: ; Anna, it's Tom. It's always a good time to buy Parker shares. We just looked at again, it's back to looking at all the opportunities, and unfortunately, we can't sure all the opportunities with you. But when we looked at all the opportunities, we felt the amount that we did was the right amount. We'll continue to look at it every quarter. We weigh obviously dividends first, investment for organic growth and then we look at the balance between acquisitions and share repurchase. For the reasons I talked about earlier, will be an indicator white Burgundy of the low end of that range because the dynamics of the row changes once we announce that proposal. We're absolutely committed to the low end of that range. I do want to be misunderstanding, things [indiscernible] top end of the range. And the balance above that is all depending on what's the best use of cash for our shareholders.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. That's very helpful clarification. And then my follow-up is back to some of the comments you made about restructuring the sales force. We get nervous when we hear companies talking about restructuring the sales force. Doesn't always work out very w
componenttext: Right. That's very helpful clarification. And then my follow-up is back to some of the comments you made about restructuring the sales force. We get nervous when we hear companies talking about restructuring the sales force. Doesn't always work out very well. It just get more detail what you're doing there and how covetable you feel about the progress you're making?

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Anna, it's Tom again. We're very, very happy with what we're doing. I can understand your reservations, but this was done with a lot of thought. And here's a big change. Our groups organized the exception of Aerospace, organized around technology and
componenttext: Yes. Anna, it's Tom again. We're very, very happy with what we're doing. I can understand your reservations, but this was done with a lot of thought. And here's a big change. Our groups organized the exception of Aerospace, organized around technology and products. And it's easier alignment for our divisions to take and find people that own those product and technologies. So in Europe as an example, we went from a sales force that was maybe heavily dominated alignment to markets to be more product-centric, still not getting of the markets but having that be less situation, so more concentration on technologies and markets so we can have a real good technology discussion with our customers. The other part we did to help simplify our interface with a global OEMs that are regionally OEMs in Europe as we now have a pan-Europe OEM team about, which is very similar to what we have in North America, which had so much success. So we have that, makes us to be calling out OEMs country-by-country that spanned the entire year. So that's been in place for probably 6, 9 months. And we are very encouraged with the kind of market share actions that we're seeing coming out of that or from that team. And then just in Japan, that was the other example that came to mind when I made that comment. In Japan, if you look at it historically, we had a very fragmented sales force. We now have a sales force that is all aligned, and it's kind of combination of acquisitions that we have, joint ventures years ago. Now we have a one Japan sales force with a much better alignment of the operating side. And we're the result of that. Japan's doing very well for us. So the organizational changes, to give you comfort, are showing in the numbers and on the market concentration so we go account-by-account for various regions.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. David, this is Tom again. That is the -- of course, the question everybody would like to know. And at this point, it's difficult for me to predict, and I won't try to predict. I mean, at this point, our guidance for the fourth quarter is a minus 7 o
componenttext: Okay. David, this is Tom again. That is the -- of course, the question everybody would like to know. And at this point, it's difficult for me to predict, and I won't try to predict. I mean, at this point, our guidance for the fourth quarter is a minus 7 organically. So that shows improvement from the minus 9.4 we had in Q3. So that's the first good sign. And like I said, these market phases when we look at all the markets, we went from a concentration in accelerant decline to now more than moved to decelerating decline. You would hope to keep moving kind of clockwise around these phases and start to move to some kind of growth. But I think it's too early for us to even give an indicator that be able to tell you when. A few more data points of a couple of more months ended couple of more quarters your company, we're going to make [indiscernible] I would say this is the first step in the healing.

componenttext: Can we talk a little bit about where inventory are, both in the distribution sense and maybe OEMs Indego? Are we really past the inventory [indiscernible]? headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eli, it's Lee. I was expecting this inventory destocking, so I researched this 10x before this call. So here's the consensus when I checked this, not only from our guys, and then I just go out and call our context. If you're involved in oil and gas and yo
componenttext: Eli, it's Lee. I was expecting this inventory destocking, so I researched this 10x before this call. So here's the consensus when I checked this, not only from our guys, and then I just go out and call our context. If you're involved in oil and gas and you had a lot of OEM exposure, you're still sitting on a lot of inventory. If you get away from that, inventory is pretty much normalized at this point in time. I think some of the guys may have got hit a little by some side effects from oil and gas, but that's fairly normalized. I would say on OEM inventory, where I still see it as kind of a construction equipment, mining markets, especially Asia comes to mind, if you tour some of the equipment yards, I mean, there's just excavators and wheel loaders going for miles. But in North America distribution, I'm most comfortable that outside of oil and gas, it's not a big issue. And then your second question on pricing. I can't really comment on that. What we did there was really noncore. So I can't really comment too much on that. I have not had any feedback that it's been a big issue. If anything, it's been a positive [indiscernible].

componenttext: Just maybe ask Russell's question a little differently. On the orders front, you guys can the BBC the comp getting easier there. Orders clearly down a little bit more than maybe the comp was guide easier this quarter. Is there a potential orders to get back to flat in June, understanding that maybe a white longer before sales quite get there?

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Josh, Jon here. Just to kind of be responsive to your question. Of course, we're not calling for that and in our guidance going forward. When you take a look at the orders overall for Parker, we are just looking at -- we were, this time last year, down 4
componenttext: Josh, Jon here. Just to kind of be responsive to your question. Of course, we're not calling for that and in our guidance going forward. When you take a look at the orders overall for Parker, we are just looking at -- we were, this time last year, down 4 then we were down 9, down 11, down 12. Now we're down 6. So the question is, what is the rate of the incline in the reduction of the orders for the company? We don't have that forecasted. We're going to be looking at that very closely. It's going to be fully aligned with the end market progress that Lee and Tom have been making. And we are gaining market share. We are watching the end markets. And as Tom said, I think our best characterization is that it's moderately, this decline is obviously moderating. But we'll be coming up with that answer when we do our guidance in August. But right now, in April, it's a little too early to give you a very detailed answer to that.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just revisit the buyback discussion. It sounds like maybe there were some mitigating factors in the quarter that stayed your hand. But is there a period of time that passes when that -- some of those other opportunities go away or inactiona
componenttext: Okay. And then just revisit the buyback discussion. It sounds like maybe there were some mitigating factors in the quarter that stayed your hand. But is there a period of time that passes when that -- some of those other opportunities go away or inactionable or are actionable? You guys our website buyback? Or is this something that is a little bit more structural in nature? Just trying to get the overall strategy there maybe versus like a one-quarter event.

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, the overall strategy hasn't changed. We want to be great generators of cash and great deployers of cash. And I think the generators of cash, though 1 strategy is can continue to work aggressively with the changes that we've made are 10.5% now.
componenttext: Yes. Well, the overall strategy hasn't changed. We want to be great generators of cash and great deployers of cash. And I think the generators of cash, though 1 strategy is can continue to work aggressively with the changes that we've made are 10.5% now. We like being there. We like to work even higher. We're going to do that through continue to grow our operating earnings and continue to work the working capital down. On the deployment, it's the same priorities that I've mentioned, just trying to make the best position. I won't read one thing aggressively in 1 a quarter on this. We're going to -- because the buyback announcement is can expire. And my preference is to tell you every quarter what we're doing is most making big announcements what we're going to do going forward. There are some natural considerations given the amount of cash permanent invested overseas, heart is our to keep an a rating, in effect, this program was rolled out 2 years ago, and a lot has changed in 2 years, approximately 2 years ago. But we like all of those avenues, and we want to be as great at deploying cash as we're great at generating the cash. And I would look for us to do that. And I can't show you everything that we see, but we'll continue to do the best we can on behalf of the shareholders for what we think is best long term.

componenttext: I think, on the mining, what we saw in general is that probably a little bit more help on the -- obviously, it'd be both. OEM, in general, is comparing Q2 to Q3 get a little bit better. This revision got a little bit better as well. But for the most part, it's probably more of the comps. They're helping us at this point. We're not ready to declare a victory in these areas. In a couple of more quarters and we see this move, then I think be ready to say it's more of the market of this points comps helping us more than anything.

componenttext: Okay. If I could get into North American margins from a different angle here. North -- on a year-over-year basis for the quarter, you just reported, organically, you lost about $200 million of revenue. All else equal, I would think that decremental should be something in the vicinity of 25%. So you started about $50 million in the haul on operating income, and you are  up about $25 million. So from other avenues, you gained about $75 million of operating income. Could you kind of bucket the main places that, that came from, where the savings came from, what's improved execution? What's productivity, those kinds of things?

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, I can't detail it down to you for the dollar. But as Tom and Lee have talked about, the productivity that we're seeing from the new Win Strategy is a significant portion of that number, Nathan. And as we apply the techniques that we've kn
componenttext: Well, certainly, I can't detail it down to you for the dollar. But as Tom and Lee have talked about, the productivity that we're seeing from the new Win Strategy is a significant portion of that number, Nathan. And as we apply the techniques that we've known for years and the ones that we are really focusing on here with the New Win strategy, we are seeing margins in a declining environment that we have never seen before. And so we're gratified by that. A significant portion is just additional incremental productivity that's not necessarily in -- to take the place of the savings that I've been talking about when we do the simplification Efforts or the restructuring efforts that we've done in the company. So I can detail it down to you dollar-by-dollar, but what is happening with the margins coming and the reason why our decrementals are so impressive is because of the dedication of our employees to redouble our efforts on productivity and the company and our ability to get savings from the restructurings that we've done in the past year.

But we're is a more pronounced organically lines on year-over-year basis in North America, but margins actually going up. So can you kind of walk us through what maybe the different types of initiatives going on the restructuring side between the 2 segments as to what might be driving even more pronounced decrementals reductions in North America?

headline: Parker-Hannifin Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Joe. Sure. Just real quick here. Top level down, although we're down higher organically, and you're absolutely right in North America, and we are in international, our decremental MRO on an adjusted basis is 13 for North America versus about 19 now.
componenttext: Yes, Joe. Sure. Just real quick here. Top level down, although we're down higher organically, and you're absolutely right in North America, and we are in international, our decremental MRO on an adjusted basis is 13 for North America versus about 19 now. In any environment, that 19, in our history, in our company, is a very impressive number. But it is distinguished from North America. I believe it has something to do with the level and depth of some of the restructuring that we're doing, a little bit of a quicker payback in restructuring in North America versus internationally. But in both cases, we're making great progress. And we're kind of -- we are seeing a little bit of a difference. But this is historically in North America and in our industrial businesses, the best we've ever done in a downturn like this, especially considering the magnitude of this downturn that we're talking about of a negative 9, 9.5 for the quarter and our guidance of negative 7 here coming up. So the short answer is very quick actions; quick recovery; dedication on the part of our management teams, both in internationally and in North America; and our ability to be resilient and adaptable as a company today versus maybe in some of the prior downturns in the past periods.
